WRITING.TEXT: It's a white art marker called Uni Posca. You can use a gel pen for finer details too.
BTW here is a video of the process https://youtu.be/R7NMKF9M8Tw
Keep at it! The lack of control that comes with watercolour is one of the things that appeals to me the most, its challenging, but lots of fun. :)

Sure.
1. About 3 weeks, but I first attempted watercolour about 10 years ago. It was the first medium I ever tried and I did a handful of landscapes back then but quickly moved on to oil and acrylic.
2. A bit of both, depending on what I'm painting and what I'm trying to achieve. Working on dry paper is much more forgiving if you're looking for control.
3. No
No not at all, there really isn't alot of detail to be honest.
Thanks. Yes I do have some masking fluid sitting right next to me and will experiment in the future. Thanks for the tips.

The items in the photo aren't extraneous. Its what I used for the painting, they are completely relevant. Also, it saves me answering questions about the materials I used for the piece. Why are you so angry mate?

Really? I didn't think I was an idiot or a moron for including the paints and my brushes in the photo. Seems harsh. It helps with perspective I thought and I guess if someone else wanted to claim this as their own it would be harder to crop out the painting and repost with the other stuff in the photo.
I'm Australian, we spell it Watercolour. I believe the brits do too.
It is me, I might make some prints available if theres enough interest.
I'm Australian, we spell it Watercolour. :)
